metadata.sermon_title: Why Modern Man Needs The Gospel
metadata.sermon_start_end: Modern man! Transplanter of human organs! Voyager to the immensities of outer space! Abolisher of distance, inventor of instantaneous communication from pole to pole, master of government, architect of his own destiny, master of his fate, and captain of his soul. [...] There is coming a day by the power of God, on this earth or elsewhere, when they will neither hurt nor kill in all his holy hill, when the place of sorrow will become the scene of joy, and the glory of the Lord will cover the earth as the waters cover the sea.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses Romans 1 as a springboard for a cultural critique rather than recreating the specific text into a new, current word. It treats the passage as a general illustration of 'idolatry' and 'pride' rather than mining what is unique to this specific pericope. It drifts into generalities about 'the gospel' rather than the specific logic of Paul's argument in Romans 1.
quotes: We are like the ancient Romans to whom Paul refers in the words of our text.
I submit to you that Paul's words describe America in this day of grace.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Identify what Romans 1:16 and 21-22 say that cannot be found anywhere else in the Bible. Focus less on 'Modern Man' as a category and more on the specific mechanism of 'darkened hearts' and 'vain imaginations' as described by Paul.

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher shows awareness of the Roman context (Senate, Appian Way, Coliseum), but this is more historical-touristic than theological-exegetical. There is no engagement with the original languages or the specific theological structure of the Epistle to the Romans. The exegesis remains on the surface of historical ruins.
quotes: Years ago I revisited the ruins of imperial Rome.
The building still stands that housed the Roman Senate...
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Move beyond the physical ruins of Rome to the theological 'ruins' Paul describes. Analyze the Greek terms for 'power' (dynamis) or 'salvation' (soteria) in their specific Pauline context.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is concrete regarding the American context (white cop, black militant, Puerto Rican worker), which aligns with Dekker's demand for specificity. However, it often lapses into general sociological observations rather than a direct application of the specific text's unique point.
quotes: The white cop, the black militant, the Puerto Rican restaurant worker is, each one, a child of God...
Now many of our national leaders seem to be persons of expediency rather than persons of faith.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Connect the specific 'vain imaginations' of the text to specific contemporary idols (e.g., technological optimism or political shrewdness) more rigorously.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a somewhat traditional 'then and now' structure. It spends significant time on the 'then' of Rome and then jumps to the 'now' of America. The hearer is not so much 'drawn into the text' as they are shown a parallel between two different times.
quotes: Old Rome had everything â€” except God... I submit to you that Paul's words describe America...
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Avoid the 'parallel' structure. Try to let the text's own movement dictate the movement of the sermon so that exposition and application happen simultaneously.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: The sermon strongly emphasizes 'misery' (the list of sins, the falling of Rome/America) and 'redemption' (the power of the gospel). It successfully avoids being 'too Christocentric' by focusing on the human condition (psychology of pride). However, 'gratitude' as a specific category of life under the Spirit is less developed.
quotes: Listen to the scope of the disaster: fornication, wickedness, covetousness...
The gospel calls modern humanity out of the facelessness of the crowd.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Deepen the 'gratitude' section by showing how the specific redemption from 'vain imaginations' leads to a specific new way of thinking and acting.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: The sermon addresses the possibility of being 'lost in time' (society perishing) and the 'ultimate possibilities' of life. It takes the hearer seriously as a responsible being. However, the 'eternal' dimension is somewhat vague ('on this earth or elsewhere').
quotes: We are drifters now with little sense of being headed anywhere in particular.
A person can be lost in time and in eternity.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Make the 'two ways' more explicit. What is the concrete 'destruction' that follows the 'broad way' of modern pride, beyond just social decay?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is mentioned as the 'telos', but the sermon leans heavily on a general 'God-consciousness' and 'human worth' rather than the specific work of Christ. Christ's divinity (two natures) is assumed but not functionally central to the argument of the sermon.
quotes: Jesus Christ calls us out of the crowd one by one...
each one of us was counted by Jesus as worth a cross on Calvary.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure Christ is not just a 'portion' or 'friend' (as in the quoted hymn), but the specific 'power of God' that reverses the specific 'darkening' mentioned in the text.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At approximately 1150 words, the sermon would take about 11-12 minutes to deliver. According to Dekker, this is insufficient for the 'breadth' required for true 'depth'. The sermon feels more like a speech or an address than a full exposition.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the exegetical depth and the theological implications of the 'power of God' to reach the 20-minute threshold.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekker's criteria primarily due to its insufficient length and its tendency to use the Bible passage as a general illustration for a cultural critique rather than an authoritative, specific word. While it successfully addresses the 'misery' of the human condition and provides concrete contemporary application, it lacks the exegetical rigor and the 'interwoven' character Dekker demands. It functions more as a religious-patriotic appeal than a 'recreation' of the written Word into a current proclamatory Word.
strengths: Concrete application to social and individual identity (Thesis 3).
Strong focus on the 'misery' of human pride and the 'facelessness' of the mass (Thesis 5).
Avoids 'general truths' in its description of the American social fabric (Thesis 3).
weaknesses: Insufficient duration (approx. 11 minutes) prevents theological depth (Thesis 8).
Exegesis is replaced by historical anecdotes about Roman ruins (Thesis 2).
The specific 'uniqueness' of the Romans 1 text is not fully exploited (Thesis 1).
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is not a sermon in the full sense of Dekker's definition. It is a substantive religious speech that lacks the necessary exegetical breadth and the formal requirement of length to be considered a proper 'exposition and application' of the Word of God.
